sp.speaker: Mr. Brown,
sp.p: I found him, my Lord, in a Ditch, with his Sword through him, and the end of it was two handfulls out of his back.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was he Bloody?

sp.speaker: Mr. Brown,
sp.p: There was no Blood at all, there was no Blood in the Ditch.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was the Sword ſticking in his Body?

sp.speaker: Mr. Brown,
sp.p: Yes, My Lord, but there was no Blood at all when it was taken out; they had run it into another place, but that happened to be againſt a Rib, and ſo it could not go through; but there was no blood there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Jones,
sp.p: Was there any bruiſes on his Breaſt?

sp.speaker: Mr. Brown,
sp.p: He did look black about the Breaſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. G.
sp.p: My Lord, I would ask, whether his Neck were broken?

sp.speaker: Mr. Brown,
sp.p: Yes, I ſuppoſe it was.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How do you know it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Brown,
sp.p: It was very weak, and one might turn his Head from one Shoulder to the other.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where was his Stick and Gloves?

sp.speaker: Mr. Brown,
sp.p: They were on the Bank-ſide.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Whoſe Sword was it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Brown,
sp.p: His Servants ſaid it was his own.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. G.
sp.p: Pray, had he any Money in his Pocket?

sp.speaker: Mr. Brown,
sp.p: Yes, a great deal of Gold and Silver.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Ay, Ay, for they count Theft Sin, but not Murder.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Wild,
sp.p: They left that, to let men think he murdered himſelf.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, will you ask this Witneſs any queſtions before he goes?

sp.speaker: Capt. Richardſon,
sp.p: They ſay they will ask him none.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. G.
Mr. Att. G.
sp.p: We begin with Mr. Skillard, Pray, Sir, inform my Lord and the Jury, Did you ſee the Body of Sir Edmondbury Godfrey?

sp.speaker: Mr. Skillard,
sp.p: Yes, I did view the Body.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. G.
sp.p: When? what time did you ſee it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Skillard,
sp.p: About Twelve of the Clock.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. G.
sp.p: What day of the Week was it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Skillard,
sp.p: On Friday, the next day after he was found.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att G.
sp.p: Did you obſerve his Breaſt? how was it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Skillard.
sp.p: His breaſt was all beaten with ſome obtuſe weapon, either with the feet or hands, or ſomething.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. G.
sp.p: Did you obſerve his neck?

sp.speaker: Mr. Skillard
sp.p: Yes, it was diſtorted.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. G.
sp.p: How far?

sp.speaker: Mr. Skillard.
sp.p: You might have taken the Chin and have ſet it upon either Shoulder.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. G.
sp.p: Did you obſerve the wound?

sp.speaker: Mr. Skillard.
sp.p: Yes, I did. It went in at one place and ſtopt at a Rib, the other place it was quite through the Body.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. G.
sp.p: Do you think he was killed by that wound?

sp.speaker: Mr. Skillard.
sp.p: No, for then there would have been ſome evacuation of Blood, which there was not. And beſides his boſome was open, and he had a Flannel Waſtcoat and a Shirt on; and neither thoſe, nor any of his Clothes were penetrated.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. G.
sp.p: But are you ſure his neck had been broken?

sp.speaker: Mr. Skillard.
sp.p: Yes, I am ſure.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. G.
sp.p: Becauſe ſome have been of opinion, that he hanged himſelf, and his Relations to ſave his eſtate run him through; I would deſire to ask the Chyrurgeon what he thinks of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Skillard.
sp.p: There was more done to his neck than an ordinary ſuffocation; the wound went through his very heart, and there would have appeared ſome blood, if it had been done quickly after his death.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. G.
sp.p: Did it appear by the view of the body that he was ſtrangled or hanged?

sp.speaker: Mr. Skillard.
sp.p: He was a lean man, and his muſcles if he had died of the wound, would have been turgid: and then again all ſtrangled people never ſwell, becauſe there is a ſudden deprivation of all the ſpirits, and a hindring of the Circulation of the blood.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. G.
sp.p: How long do you believe he might be dead before you ſaw him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Skillard.
sp.p:
I believe four or five days. And they might have kept him a week and he never ſwell'd at all, being a lean man. And when we ript him up, he began for to putrify, we made two inciſions to give it vent, and the liquor that was in his body did a little ſmell. The very lean fleſh was ſo
near turned into putrefaction, that it ſtuck to the Inſtrument when we cut it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: My Lord here is another Chyrurgeon, Mr. Cambridge; Pray Sir are you ſworn.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cambridge.
sp.p: Yes, I am.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: When did you ſee the body of Sir Edmondbury Godfrey?

sp.speaker: Mr. Cambridge.
sp.p: Upon friday, the very ſame day the Gentleman did. I found his neck diſlocated, and his breaſt very much beaten and bruiſed. And I found two punctures under his left Pap, the one went againſt the Rib, the other quite through the body under the left Pap.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att G.
sp.p: Do you believe that wound was the occaſion of his death?

sp.speaker: Mr. Cambridge.
sp.p: No, I believe it was given him after his death.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And his neck was broke?

sp.speaker: Mr. Cambridge.
sp.p: His neck was diſlocated, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. G.
sp.p: Why, that is broken. Now my Lord we ſhall call Sir Edmundbury Godfreys Maid, Elizabeth Curtis. Swear her. Which was done.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip knows that Mr Praunce did ſay in the beginning, that they had been ſeveral times at his Houſe inquiring for him: now we call this perſon to tell you what ſhe knows about that.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. G.
sp.p: Elizabeth Curtis, look upon the Priſoners, and tell my Lord and the Jury whether you know any of them or no.

sp.speaker: Elizabeth Curtis.
sp.p: This man that I now hear called Green, my Lord, was at my Maſters about a fortnight before he died.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What to do?

sp.speaker: Eliz. Curtis.
sp.p: I don't know, but he asked for Sir Edmondbury Godfrey.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What time of the day was it?

sp.speaker: Eliz. Curtis,
sp.p: It was in the morning.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att G.
sp.p: What did he ſay?

sp.speaker: Eliz Curtis,
sp.p: He asked for Sir Edmondbury Godfrey, and when he came to him, he ſaid, Good morrow, Sir, in Engliſh, and afterwards ſpoke to him in French, I could not underſtand him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder,
sp.p: I deſire ſhe may conſider well, and look upon him.

sp.speaker: Eliz. Curtis,
sp.p: That is the man.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Upon my Soul I never ſaw him in all my life.

sp.speaker: Eliz. Curtis,
sp.p: He had a darker coloured Perriwig when he was there, and was about a quarter of an hour talking with my Maſter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. G.
sp.p: Are you ſure this was the man?

sp.speaker: E. Curtis,
sp.p: Yes, I am, and that other man Hill was there that Saturday morning, and did ſpeak with him before he went out.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: That you will deny too?

sp.speaker: Hill,
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How do you know he was there?

sp.speaker: E. Curtis,
sp.p: I was in the Parlor at that time, making up the fire.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Had you ever ſeen him before that time?

sp.speaker: E. Curtis,
sp.p: No, never before that time. I went into the Parlor to carry my Maſter his Break-faſt, and brought a bunch of Keys with me in, and there Hill was with him. And I went up ſtairs about ſome buſineſs, and came down again wanting the Keys, which I had left upon the Table; and Hill was all that time with my Maſter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. G.
sp.p: How do you know he was there?

sp.speaker: E. Curtis,
sp.p: I was in the Parlor and ſtirred up the fire, and he was there a good while.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Jones,
sp.p: How long after did you ſee him again?

sp.speaker: E. Curtis,
sp.p: Not till I ſaw him in Newgate.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Jones,
sp.p: How long was that afterwards?

sp.speaker: E. Curtis,
sp.p: A month ago. But it is not the man that brought the note to my Maſter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. G.
sp.p: What note?

sp.speaker: E. Curtis,
sp.p: A note that a man brought to my Maſter that night before.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. G.
sp.p: What is become of that Note?

sp.speaker: E. Curtis,
sp.p: My Lord, I cannot tell, my Maſter had it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. G.
sp.p: Prithee, tell us the ſtory of it.

sp.speaker: E. Curtis,
sp.p:
There was a man came to my Maſters Houſe, and asked if Sir Edmondbury Godfrey were within. He ſaid he had a Letter for him; and ſhewed it me, it was tied up in a knot.
I told him my Maſter was within, but buſy; but ſaid I, if you pleaſe I will carry it into him: he did ſo, and I gave it to my Maſter; when I went out again, the man ſtaid and asked for an Anſwer: I went in again and told my Maſter that the man required an Anſwer. Prithee, ſaid he, tell him I don't know what to make of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Wild,
sp.p: When was that?

sp.speaker: E. Curtis,
sp.p: On Friday night.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Wild,
sp.p: When? The Friday night before he was murdered?

sp.speaker: E. Curtis,
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. G.
sp.p: But you Swear that Hill was there the Saturday morning.

sp.speaker: E. Curtis,
sp.p: Yes, he was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. G.
sp.p: In what Clothes was he then?

sp.speaker: E. Curtis,
sp.p: The ſame Clothes that he hath now.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Wild,
sp.p: Are you ſure they are the ſame Clothes?

sp.speaker: E. Curtis,
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. G.
L. C. J.
sp.p: Have you ever ſhifted your Clothes?

sp.speaker: Hill,
sp.p: No indeed, I have not.

sp.speaker: E. Curtis,
sp.p: But for the man that brought the Note, I cannot Swear it is he.

sp.speaker: Hill,
sp.p: But ſhe did ſay when ſhe came to ſee me in Newgate, that ſhe never ſaw me in my life; and my Lord I hope I have ſufficient VVitneſſes to prove where I was that morning.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: She ſays, ſhe cannot Swear you were the man that brought the Note.

sp.speaker: Hill,
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire ſhe will tell me about what time it was I was there.

sp.speaker: E. Curtis,
sp.p: It was about nine or ten a Clock.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. G.
sp.p: That agrees with Mr. Praunces exactly in point of time. Now if your Lordſhip pleaſe, we will proceed and call Mr. Lancellot Stringer, and Mr. Vincent.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder,
sp.p: My Lord, we do call theſe Witneſſes to prove, that theſe men had meetings with Mr. Praunce at the Plow.

div.stage: [Then was Lancelot Stringer ſworn.]

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Pray tell my Lord and the Jury whether you know Mr. Prance.

sp.speaker: L. Stringer.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Have you ſeen him at the Plow at any time?

sp.speaker: L. Stringer.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I have.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: In what company there? Was Mr. Green there?

sp.speaker: L. Stringer.
sp.p: Yes, he was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Which was he? He points to him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: And who elſe?

sp.speaker: L. Stringer.
sp.p: There was that Hill.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How often?

sp.speaker: L. Stringer.
sp.p: Several times.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long before Sir Edmundbury Godfrey was murdered?

sp.speaker: L. Stringer.
sp.p: I cannot tell, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you remember any other company was with him?

sp.speaker: L. Stringer.
sp.p: Yes, there were ſeveral other company.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Name them.

sp.speaker: L. Stringer.
sp.p: There was Mr. Fitz-Girald and Mr. Hill.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: And yet Hill ſaith he never ſaw Girald.

sp.speaker: L. Stringer.
sp.p: And there was Kelly, he was another of them, and Prance.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you know Vernatt?

sp.speaker: L. Stringer.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How now? What ſay you to it Mr. Hill, and Mr. Green? Were you never at the Plow, drinking with Mr. Prance?

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, ſeveral times.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What ſay you, Mr Green?

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: I have drank with him there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you know Girald?

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: I know one Girald?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Now will your Lordſhip pleaſe to let me prove, that at the Council he owned he knew Girald and Kelly, and now 'tis proved he hath been in Kelly's company, he ſays he does not know Girald.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: My Lord, that was a miſtake, for I do know Kelly by ſight, that is, I knew two Men that uſed the Chappel very much, and he was one of them.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But you, Witneſs, ſay you have ſeen Girald and them together?

sp.speaker: L. Stringer.
sp.p: Yes, I have.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How many times?

sp.speaker: L. Stringer.
sp.p: I cannot tell how many, my Lord, ſeveral times.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Have you ſeen them twice together?

sp.speaker: L. Stringer.
sp.p: Yes, I have.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Now to ſettle it I would ask him, with your Lordſhips favour, when he came to live with his Maſter. You, young Man, when did you come to live with your Maſter at the Plow?

sp.speaker: L. Stringer.
sp.p: Why, I have been with him two years.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rec.
sp.p: But when was it you came laſt to live at the Plow?

sp.speaker: L. Stringer.
sp.p: In Bartholomew-tide laſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: It was but five Weeks before Sir Edmondbury Godfrey was Murdered.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you, Green, know Mr. Girald?

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Then pray Swear Mr. Vincent. [Which was done.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Come, pray Sir, do you live at the Plow?

sp.speaker: Vincent.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Then pray, do you tell my Lord, and the Jury, if you know any of the Priſoners at the Bar, and which of them.

sp.speaker: Vincent.
sp.p: I know Mr. Green.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Do you know any body elſe?

sp.speaker: Vincent.
sp.p: Yes, I know Hill, and I know Mr. Berry.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rec.
sp.p: Have you ſeen theſe perſons at your Houſe?

sp.speaker: Vincent.
sp.p: Yes, I have.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: With whom?

sp.speaker: Vincent.
sp.p: I can't tell every body with whom they were.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Were they there with Praunce?

sp.speaker: Vincent.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you know one Girald?

sp.speaker: Vincent.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Hath he been at your houſe?

sp.speaker: Vincent.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, he hath.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who was with him?

sp.speaker: Vincent.
sp.p: I can't tell juſtly.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you know Kelly?

sp.speaker: Vincent.
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Hath he been there?

sp.speaker: Vincent.
sp.p: Yes, he hath.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: In what Company?

sp.speaker: Vincent.
sp.p: With Praunce.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And with any of the Priſoners?

sp.speaker: Vincent.
sp.p: Yes, but I can't tell particularly with whom.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: Now, my Lord, as theſe were meetings before the fact was committed to conſult how to do it; ſo we at the beginning told you of a meeting after it was done, and that was at Bow. We ſhall therefore call ſome Witneſſes as to that; and they are Richard Cary, and William Evans. Firſt ſwear Richard Cary. [Which was done.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
Cary.
sp.p: I remember it very well; there were three Gentlemen that ſent for me to the Queens-Head, and I being ſent for did come, and when I came up ſtairs, they asked me if I knew Poplar, I ſaid I knew it very well. Then they asked me if I knew Mr. Dethick, I told them I thought I did. Then ſaid they, you muſt carry this Letter to George Dethick, Eſq at Poplar, and deliver it to his own hands, and to no body elſe. Accordingly away I went, and carried the Letter: I went to the door, and asked if he were within; his Man ſaid he was above ſtairs, but they would call him to me; and calling him to me, Sir, ſaid I, there are ſome Gentlemen at the Queens-Head at Bow that have ſent me with a Letter to you. So he looked upon the Letter, and, ſaith he, go and tell them I will be with them preſently. So, may it pleaſe you, my Lord, I came again, and when I came, the Gentlemen were there ſtill. Well, ſaid they, go and drink a Glaſs of Claret, which ſtood upon the Table, and they gave me Six-pence, and I went away.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Pray look upon Mr. Praunce, can you remember whether that man was there?

sp.speaker: Cary.
sp.p: There were three of them, and he looks like one.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Mr. Praunce, do you remember this was the man you ſent?

sp.speaker: Mr. Praunce.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, this was the ſame man that was ſent.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, call the other.

div.stage: [Then William Evans, the Boy of the Houſe at the Queens-Head, was ſworn]

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Hark you, do you remember any Company that was at your Maſters houſe two or three Months agon?

sp.speaker: W. Evans.
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Do you remember that you heard them talk any thing there?

sp.speaker: W. Evans.
sp.p: They pull'd out a Paper and read it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You Boy, do you know Mr. Dethick?

sp.speaker: W. Evans.
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was he there?

sp.speaker: W. Evans.
sp.p: He did come to them, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: What had they to Dinner there?

sp.speaker: W. Evans.
sp.p: They had Flounders.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Who bought them?

sp.speaker: W. Evans.
sp.p: One of them, I can't tell who.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: What had they elſe?

sp.speaker: W. Evans.
sp.p: A Barrel of Oyſters.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Pray give my Lord an accompt what you obſerved and heard.

sp.speaker: W. Evans.
sp.p: Sir, I know nothing but that they pull'd out a Paper, and read it, and named Sir Edmondbury Godfrey's Name. And while I was at the door, ſome body came and threatned to kick me down ſtairs.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He ſaith juſt as Mr. Praunce ſaid in every particular.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: Now if it pleaſe your Lordſhip, we deſire to call Sir Robert Southwell, to prove what Mr. Praunce ſaid before the Council, and how particular he was; and did to ſome of the Lords, who were ſent with him to Somerſet-Houſe, point out the places.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: We call him to ſhew, that when Praunce was examined before the King, he was ſent with ſome of the Lords, and Sir Robert Southwell, to Somerſet-Houſe, where he pointed with his Finger, and ſhewed the places where all was done, and ſo we ſhall ſhew your Lordſhip and the Jury, how exact he was in every thing.

div.stage: Then Sir Robert Southwell was ſworn.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Pray Sir Robert, will you tell your knowledge?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert Southwell.
sp.p: My Lord, I was upon the twenty fourth of December waiting upon his Majeſty in Council, and Mr. Praunce was ſent for, to ſpeak his knowledge concerning this Murder, and he then gave a general Account of things, which, becauſe it did relate to that Bench, and this Corner, and that Room, and that Paſſage, and that Gallery, it was not underſtood by the Board, and thereupon his Majeſty thought fit to appoint my Lord Duke of Monmouth, and the Earl of Oſſory, and Mr. Vice-Chamberlain to the Queen, to go thither, and take the Examination upon the place, and Report it to the Board: And I, being Clerk of of the Council, though not in waiting at that time, and having taken notice of what Mr. Praunce had there depoſed, I did wait upon thoſe Lords, and took the Examination upon the Place. And what I did take upon the place, This was done here, and that there, I drew up into a Report, and the Report is Signed by thoſe two Noble Lords, and was read that Afternoon at the Board; and to that I referr my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attorn. Gen.
sp.p: Pray Sir Robert, Did he ſhew the particular places to thoſe Lords?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert Southwell.
sp.p:
Yes, he did. Firſt, the Bench whereon they were ſitting when Sir Edmondbury Godfrey was coming down; then the Corner into which they drew him when they had ſtrangled him; then the place where one Berry went to ſtay, which was at the Stairs that lead to the Upper Court, then a little door at the end of the Stables, which lead up a pair of Stairs, and at the head of the Stairs a long dark Entry, and at the top of thoſe Staires, a door on the left hand, which being opened, ſhew'd us eight ſteps, which lead up to the Lodgings that were Dr. Godwins: In which Hill was ſaid to be inhabitant for ſeven years before. And
aſſoon as we were gone two ſteps, there was a little Cloſet or Cabinet on the right hand, in which there was a Bed, and there he ſhewed my Lords, This is the place where we handed him up firſt, and here we left him, ſaid he, in the care of Hill for two nights.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Wild.
sp.p: You were there, Sir Robert Southwell upon the place, when he ſhew'd them theſe things?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert Southwell.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I was there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Wild.
sp.p: Was it anſwerable to what he had declared to the King and Council?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert Southwell.
sp.p: Yes, it was anſwerable to all things he had ſaid in the morning.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Jones.
sp.p: And ſuitable to what he ſays now?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert Southwell.
sp.p: Yes, ſuitable to what he ſayes now, but only now he ſayes more than he ſaid then. And as to what he ſayes about the Chambers of Sir John Arundell, they could not be Sir John's Lodgings, for they were not capable of receiving a Perſon of that Quality.

sp.speaker: Mr. Praunce.
sp.p: I ſaid, I did believe they did belong to Sir John Arundell.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Juſt.
sp.p: They were Lodgings perhaps that belong'd to his Servants, though not to him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attorn. Gen.
sp.p: Sir Robert, I deſire to know, whether Mr. Praunce, when he ſhew'd theſe places, and made theſe Deſcriptions, did he do it with any heſitancy, or did he do it readily?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert Southwell.
sp.p:
Hitherto, my Lord, he went directly and poſitively, as if any body ſhould walk to Weſtminſter-Hall door. But afterwards, when the Lords did deſire to know whither the Body was carried, he ſaid, it was into ſome Room of the houſe by the Garden; for this is an Outer part of the Houſe, which any body may do any thing in, without their knowledge that are within. And he undertook to lead them
to the place as well as he could; and ſo away we went through the long dark Entry that leads into the Outer Court of the Great Houſe; and croſsing the Quadrangle, he leads us to the Piazza, and down a pair of Stairs, and ſo far, ſaid he, I am ſure I went; then, aſſoon as we were down the Stairs, there is a great Square Court, then he began to ſtagger, as if he did not know his way, but there was no way but to go on hovvever, and on vve vvent, and coming croſs the Court, vve came into ſeveral Rooms, and going through them, vve came up Stairs again, and ſo into ſeveral other Rooms again. Sure, ſaid he, vve vvere here, but I can't tell, and he vvas in a great Diſtraction vvhat Room he ſavv the Body in; but, ſaid he, thus far, I am certain I am right; vvhich vvas according to the Paper, and I refer my ſelf to that.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Wild.
sp.p: But, you ſay, that what he had ſaid to the Lords in the Council, was the ſame that he ſaid when you were by upon the place.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert Southwell.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. Chief. Juſt.
sp.p: His doubtfulneſs of the Room does aſſert, and give Credit to his Teſtimony, and Confirms it to any honeſt man in England. Here, ſaith he, I will not be poſitive, but having ſworn the other things which he well remembred, poſitively, he is made the more Credible for his doubtfulneſs of a thing which he does not remember, which a man that could ſwear any thing would not ſtick at.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Jones.
sp.p: Beſides, he was not there but by night, and all the Light he had was a dark Lanthorn.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Now, Sir Robert, I would ask you one Queſtion, if you pleaſe, Do you remember that Hill was Examined at the Council about this matter?

sp.speaker: Sir Robert Southwell.
sp.p: My Lord theſe are the Notes that I took upon theſe Mens Examinations, if your Lordſhip pleaſes they may be read.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Sir Robert, We ask you but as to one particular thing, therefore if you pleaſe to look upon it, and refreſh your Memory, you may read it to your ſelf, and tell us only the ſubſtance; which he did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Now Sir, if you pleaſe, Do you remember that Hill was there?

sp.speaker: Sir. Rob. Southwell.
sp.p: Yes, I find he was Examined.

sp.speaker: Mr. Soll. Gen.
sp.p: Did not he deny there that he knew Kelly, but that he knew Girald?

sp.speaker: Sir Rob. Southwell.
sp.p: Yes, I do find it here ſet down that he did deny he knew Kelly, but that he knew Girald.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: I ſaid I knew one Girald, but not that.

sp.speaker: Mr. Record.
sp.p: But before the Council he ſaid he knew Girald, not one Girald.

sp.speaker: L. Chief Juſt.
sp.p: This way of Anſwering is like the Examination that was taken lately amongſt ſome of them. A Perſon was asked when he ſaw ſuch a Prieſt? He denied that he had ſeen him in fourteen dayes. But then comes one and proves to his face, that he was with him in Company all Night, within a Week and Ieſs. I, ſayes he, that's true, but I ſaid I had not ſeen him in Fourteen Dayes. And ſo they may take Oaths to ſerve the King faithfully all the Dayes of their Lives, but in the Nights they may murther him, and keep their Oaths for all that.

sp.speaker: Mr Juſt. Dolben.
sp.p: I would know, whether the Girald you know be a Prieſt or no?

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: He is not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Dolben.
sp.p: Then you do not know Girald the Prieſt?

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: No, I do not.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Call Mr. Thomas Stringer. And he was ſworn.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Pray Mr. Stringer, will you tell my Lord and the Jury what it was that Mr. Berry ſaid about any directions he had to keep all Perſons out of Somerſet-Houſe, about the twelfth or fourteenth of October laſt?

sp.speaker: Mr. T. Stringer.
sp.p: My Lord, upon his Examination before the Lords of the Committee, Berry did ſay he had Orders from the Queen, or in the Name of the Queen, That he ſhould ſuffer no Strangers, nor any Perſons of Quality to come into Somerſet-Houſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: When was it he was to keep them out?

sp.speaker: Mr. T. Stringer.
sp.p: The 12th 13th and 14th of October.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What, three days?

sp.speaker: Mr. T. Stringer.
sp.p: Two or three days. And he ſaid that the Prince did come, and he did refuſe him, and ſent him back again.

sp.speaker: Mr. Record.
sp.p: Did he ſay he ever had any ſuch Directions before?

sp.speaker: Mr. T. Stringer.
sp.p: No: he ſaid he never before had any.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: It was a very unlucky thing that he had it then.

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: The Prince might have gone in if he would.

sp.speaker: Mr. T. Stringer.
sp.p: You ſaid you did refuſe him, you had order to let none come in.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Had you any ſuch Order?

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I had ſuch an Order from the Queen's Gentleman-Uſher.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Just.
sp.p: Had you never had ſuch before?

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: Yes, I have had before, ſince the Queen came to Somerſet-Houſe.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Mr. Stringer ſwears you ſaid you had not any before.

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: Yes, I had.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Why did you deny it then?

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: I did not deny it; beſides, there were ſeveral went in.

sp.speaker: Mr. Record.
sp.p: We have proved indeed, five or ſix did go in.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: For how many days had you that Order?

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: Two days.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Which two days?

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: The eleventh and twelfth, I think thereabouts.

sp.speaker: Mr. Record.
sp.p: Did you ſay before the Lords, that you never had ſuch Orders before?

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: No, I did not.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Mr. Berry, When you were examined before the Lords, Did you not ſay you never had ſuch Orders before?

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: No, I did not ſay ſo, my Lord, as I know of; for they did not examine me about that.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: You ſaid you would prove it under his own Hand. Prove that.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Mr. Stringer, Did he write his Name to his Examination?

sp.speaker: Mr. T. Stringer.
sp.p: Yes, he did to one Examination.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray look upon that, Is that his Hand?

sp.speaker: Mr. T. Stringer.
sp.p: This was read to him before he Signed it, and then he did Sign it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: I would ſain ſhew it to him, to ſee whether he Would own it or no.

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: Yes, that is my Hand.

div.stage: Then the Clerke of the Crown read it.

sp.speaker: Cler. of th' Cr.
sp.p: This is ſubſcribed by Henry Berry. The Information of Henry Berry, Porter at the Gate of Somerſet-Houſe; taken before the Right Honourable the Marqueſs of Wincheſter. This Deponent ſaith, That about the 12th, 13th, and 14th of October laſt, he had Order to tell all Perſons of Quality, that the Queen was private, and that they were not to come in; and this Deponent ſaith, The Queen continued ſo private for two days.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Where is that part of the Examination wherein he ſaid, he never had any ſuch Order before?

sp.speaker: Mr. T. Sringer.
sp.p: He did ſay ſo, but it is not in that that hath his Hand to it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Wild.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, obſerve this is a kind of reflecting Evidence, and I Would have no more made of it than the thing will bear.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: They only bring it, and make uſe of it againſt Berry, as a pretence of his.

sp.speaker: M. Juſt. Wild.
sp.p: But it is a very reflecting Evidence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Surely there is no body here that offers it as ſuch: We uſe it only to this purpoſe, to ſhew that Berry, who was a Party to this Murder, did uſe all the means that he could to keep it private; and • ndeavoured to prevent Strangers coming in that Night to diſcover it, and therefore pretended theſe Orders.

If he had any ſuch Orders, I ſuppoſe he will prove them, we do not ſay he had them; but 'tis a great Evidence, when he pretended to ſuch privacie, that he and his Fellows had ſomething to do that was not fit to be known by every body.

sp.speaker: Mr. Record.
sp.p: He may make uſe of any body's Name, and pretend what he will; but I ſuppoſe he will prove it from the Gentleman-Uſher, if it be true.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: We have one Witneſs more to call, my Lord, and that is one Farr. Call Stephen Farr.
Which was done, and he ſworn.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: He is a Neighbour to Berry, and will give your Lordſhip an Account what Applications have been made to him, to tamper with him for Money, to keep away, and not give Evidence in this Cauſe. Pray Sir, are you Mr. Berry's Neighbour?

sp.speaker: Farr.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I am.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att Gen.
sp.p: Pray then tell what you know.

sp.speaker: Farr.
sp.p: I know him very well, his Wife hath been with me laſt Week, and asked me if I knew what time he was with me on Wedneſday, the 16th of October. I deſired time to recollect my ſelf: And ſhe called four or five times after, and I did recollect my Memory and told her, That I was not with him at all that Wedneſday.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Why, this was reaſonable, and fair enough to do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: It was ſo, my Lord, but pray had you no Money offered you?

sp.speaker: Farr.
sp.p: No Sir, none at all; and I told her I could not remember that I was with him that day.

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: But you may remember it very well, when I came from the Queen, I came to you.

sp.speaker: Farr.
sp.p: My Lord, I was out of Town that Wedneſday, from two a Clock in the Afternoon, till nine at Night.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Well, well, this is nothing: The Woman was willing if ſhe could, to have counterproved the Evidence, and what ſhe did was fair; ſhe offered no Money, nor did it in an indirect way.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, We have now done with our Evidence for the King, and leave it till we hear what they ſay.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: What do you ſay for your ſelves, you ſhall have all the free liberty you will deſire?

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p:
In the firſt place, I take God to be my Witneſs, that
I am wholly innocent, as to the Matter that is charged upon me: And as to what is ſaid, that I dogg'd Sir Edmund-Bury Godfrey; I can prove that I went into my Lodging at eight a clock, and did not ſtir out.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Come, call your Witneſſes.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Mary Tilden, Katherine Lee, Mrs. Broadſtreet, and Daniel Gray.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Let them come in there.

div.stage: Then Mary Tilden was firſt examined.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen
sp.p: This is Doctor Godwin's Niece, and his Houſe-keeper.

sp.speaker: L Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Well, what do you ask her?

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: I deſire to know what you can ſay about my being in my Lodging, and not going out.

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden.
sp.p: He hath lived in our Family ſeven or eight Years.

sp.speaker: L Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Your Family, What is your Family?

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden
sp.p: With my Uncle?

sp.speaker: L Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Who is Your Uncle.

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden.
sp.p: Doctor Godwin; we left him in the Houſe always when we were abſent from it, he was always a truſty Servant, never kept ill hours, always came home by eight a Clock at Night.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Dolben.
sp.p: Always, For how long?

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden.
sp.p: Ever ſince we came over laſt into England.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt Dolben.
sp.p: When was that?

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden.
sp.p: In April laſt.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Were you there that Night Sir Edmund-Bury Godfrey was kill'd?

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden.
sp.p: I was.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: VVhat Night was that?

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden.
sp.p: I don't know, my Lord, I heard of it in the Town.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: VVhen did you firſt hear of it?

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden
sp.p: The Thurſday that he was found.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Did you not hear of it on the Wedneſday?

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: VVho could tell you the Wedneſday before?

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden.
sp.p: Why, my Lord, in the Town it was ſaid he was miſſing from Saturday, and a Thurſday he was found.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What can you ſay concerning Hill, that he was not out after eight a clock that night?

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden.
sp.p: He was a very good Servant to my Unkle, and never kept ill hours, but always came in by eight a clock or before.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Dolben.
sp.p: Were not you out your ſelf that night?

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden.
sp.p: No not I, never out after that hour.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Pray how can you give ſuch an accompt of Mr. Hill, as if he was always in your company?

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden.
sp.p: He came in to wait at Table, and did not ſtir out afterwards.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Pray what Religion are you of? are you a Papiſt?

sp.speaker: Mary, Tilden.
sp.p: I know not whether I come here to make a profeſſion of my Faith.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Are you a Roman Catholick?

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Have you a diſpenſation to eat Suppers on Saturday-nights?

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: I hope you did not keep him company after Supper all night.

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden.
sp.p: No I did not, but he came in to wait at Table at Supper.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I thought you had kept faſting on Saturday-nights.

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden.
sp.p: No, my Lord, not on Saturday-nights.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Jones.
sp.p: How many Diſhes of Meat had you to Supper?

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden.
sp.p: We had no Meat, though we did not faſt.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Can you ſpeak poſitively as to this night, the Saturday that he was kill'd?

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden.
sp.p: He was at home that night.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And where was he the Sunday?

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden.
sp.p: He was at home.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And you are ſure he was at home every night?

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden.
sp.p: Yes, while we were in Town.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where was you all that Wedneſday-night you ſpeak of?

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden.
sp.p: I was at home in my Lodging.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Wild.
sp.p: How is it poſſible for you to ſay, that Hill, who was not your conſtant Companion, did not go out afterwards?

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden.
sp.p: No, he was not my conſtant Companion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Wild.
sp.p: How then can you charge your Memory that he was at home?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Come, you are to ſpeak truth, though you are not upon your Oath. Can you charge your memory to ſay, that he came in conſtantly at eight a clock at night?

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden.
L. C. J.
sp.p: Maid, can you ſay that he was always at home at night?

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden.
sp.p: I can ſay he never was abroad after eight at night.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: Why you did not watch him till he went to bed, did you?

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden.
sp.p: We were always up till eleven a clock at night.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. G.
sp.p: Was he in your company all that while?

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden.
sp.p: I beg your pardon; if your Lordſhip ſaw the Lodgings, you would ſay it were impoſſible for any to go in or out, but that they muſt know it within. We were conſtant in our hours of going to Supper; our doors were never opened after he came in to wait at Supper.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You may ſay any thing to a Heretick for a Papiſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice. Dolben.
sp.p: This is a mighty improbable buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice. Wild.
sp.p: Where was he a Wedneſday-night?

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden.
sp.p: At home.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: They have a general Anſwer for all Queſtions.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Jones.
sp.p: Who kept the Key of your Lodgings?

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden.
sp.p: The Maid.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Jones.
sp.p: Hath Hill never kept the Key?

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden.
sp.p: No, my Lord, the Maid.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Jones.
sp.p: How do you know but that the Maid might let him out?

sp.speaker: Mr. Praunce.
sp.p: My Lord, Mrs. Broadſtreet ſaid at firſt there was but one Key; but before the Duke of Monmouth ſhe ſaid there was ſix or ſeven Keys.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p:
Look you what tricks you put upon us to blind
us. You come and tell us that he was every night at home by eight a clock, and did not ſtir out, for there was but one Lock, and the Maid kept the Key; and yet there were three or four Keys to it.

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden.
sp.p: There was but one Key to that which kept the door faſt.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Praunce, how many Keys were there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Praunce.
sp.p: She confeſſed there were four or five.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Wild.
sp.p: What time was it that you carried him out of Somerſet-Houſe on Wedneſday-night?

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: It was about ten or eleven of the clock. Hill went to fetch the horſe.

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden.
sp.p: We had never been out of our Lodgings after eight a Clock, ſince we came to Town.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Jones.
sp.p: When were you out of Town?

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden.
sp.p: In October.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Dolben.
sp.p: Nay, now, Miſtris, you have ſpoil'd all; for in October this buſineſs was done.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Jones.
sp.p: You have undone the man, inſtead of ſaving him.

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden.
sp.p: Why, my Lord; I only miſtook the Month.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You Woman (ſpeaking to Mrs Broadſtreet what Month was it you were out of Town?

sp.speaker: Broadſtreet.
sp.p: In September.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: 'Tis apparent you conſider not what you ſay, or you come hither to ſay any thing will ſerve the turn.

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden.
sp.p: No, I do not, for I was out of Town in September, came to Town the latter end of September.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You muſt remember what you ſaid, that you came to England in April laſt, and from that time he was always within at eight a clock at night.

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden.
sp.p: Except that time that we were out of Town, which was in September the Summer-time. And it is impoſſible but if the Body was in the Houſe, as Praunce ſaid it was, but I muſt ſee him, or ſome of us muſt. I uſed to go every day into that little Room for ſomething or other, and I muſt needs ſee him if he were there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
Mr. Juſtice Jones.
sp.p: Well, Woman, what ſay you?

sp.speaker: Broadſtreet.
sp.p: We came to Town upon a Monday, Michaelmas-day was the Sunday following; and from that time neither he nor the Maid uſed to be abroad after eight a clock: we kept very good hours, and he always waited at Supper, and never went abroad after he came in to wait at Supper: and the Lodging was ſo little, that nothing could be brought in, but they muſt know that were within.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: This is a lower Room than the Chamber, is it not?

sp.speaker: Mr. Praunce.
sp.p: 'Tis even with the Dining-Room, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What ſay you, Sir Robert Southwell?

sp.speaker: Sir Ro. Southwell.
sp.p: My Lord, it is an extraordinary little place; as ſoon as you get up eight ſteps, there is a little ſquare Entry, and there is this Room on the one hand, and the Dining-Room on the other. I think there is a pair of ſtaires to go down at one corner of the Entry, as I think, but the Body was laid in a little ſquare Room at the head of the ſteps.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And muſt you go into the Room to go to the Dining-Room?

sp.speaker: Broadſtreet.
sp.p: No, 'tis a diſtinct Room; but the Key was always in the door, and every day ſome body went into it for ſomething or another.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Will you undertake to ſay it was always in the door?

sp.speaker: Broadſtreet.
sp.p: Yes, it conſtantly was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Wild.
sp.p: For my own part I will not judge you: but that his Body ſhould be carried there about nine a clock at night a Saturday-night, and remain there till Monday-night, 'tis very ſuſpitious, that if you were in the Houſe, as you ſay you were, and uſed to go into that Room every day, you muſt either hear it brought in, or ſee it.

sp.speaker: Broadſtreet.
sp.p: But we did neither, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Dolben.
sp.p: It is well you are not Indicted.

sp.speaker: Broadſtreet. Mr. Praunce,
sp.p: you know all theſe things to be falſe, Mr Praunce.

sp.speaker: Mr. Praunce.
sp.p: I lay nothing to your charge; but you ſaid before the Duke of Monmouth, that Hill was gone from his Lodgings before that time.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What ſay you, Sir Rob. Southwell?

sp.speaker: Sr. Rob. South.
sp.p: There aroſe a little quarrel between them about the time that Mr. Hill did leave thoſe Lodgings. Prance ſaid it was a Fortnight after; Hill ſaid when he was upon his Examination, that the ſame Saturday that Sr. Edmondbury was miſſing, he was treating with his Landlord, and from that time, to the time he went to his new Houſe, it was about a Week or a Fortnight.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: But he did pretend he was gone before?

sp.speaker: Broadſtreet.
sp.p: No my Lord, I did not.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: To Witneſſes upon Oath Sware it, and you ſaid it your ſelf, and gave it under your Hand.

sp.speaker: Broadſtreet.
sp.p: My Lord?—

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Nay you will not hear, but you will talk, you ſay one thing now, and you ſet another under your Hand.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. G.
sp.p: Have you not a Brother that is in the Proclamation, one Broadſtreet a Prieſt?

sp.speaker: Broadſtreet.
sp.p: I have a Brother whoſe name is Broadſtreet.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. G.
sp.p: Is he not a Prieſt, and in the Proclamation?

sp.speaker: Broadſtreet.
sp.p: I hope, I muſt not Impeach my Brother here I ſaid upon my Oath he came to Town a Monday, and Michaelmas day was the Sunday following, and Lawrence Hill went away a Fortnight after.

sp.speaker: Sr. Rob. South.
sp.p: She Swore then two or three Days after Michaelmas Day.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: You muſt know we can underſtand you through all your Arts. It was not convenient for you at that time to ſay, that Mr. Hill went away about a Fortnight after Michaelmas, for then the thing that was charged to be done part of it in your Houſe, would have been within the Fortnight, for it was the 12th of October, but then you ſaid only two or three Days.

sp.speaker: Sr. Rob. South.
sp.p: She did ſay my Lord, that about Miclemas two or three or four Days after he went away:

sp.speaker: Broadſtreet.
sp.p: I begg your pardon, I only ſaid I could not tell the time exactly.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Well have you any more to ſay.

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden.
sp.p: There was never a Day but I went into that Room for ſomething or other, and if any body came to ſee me, there was ſo little ſpace that the Footmen were always forced to be in that Room.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Dolben.
sp.p: Were you there upon Sunday?

sp.speaker: Mary Tilden.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Dolb.
sp.p: Well I will ſay no more, call another Witneſs.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Katharine Lee.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: What can you ſay, Maid?

sp.speaker: Lee.
sp.p: My Lord, I did never miſs him out of the Houſe at thoſe Hours.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: May be you did not look for him.

sp.speaker: Lee.
sp.p: I did go down every Night to the Door to ſee if it were lockt, and I went into the Parlor to ſee that things were ſafe there.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: You are a Roman Catholick, are you not?

sp.speaker: Lee.
sp.p: Yes, I am.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Dolben.
sp.p: Might not he go out of the Houſe, and you never the wiſer?

sp.speaker: Lee.
sp.p: Yes, for I did not watch him continually.

sp.speaker: Capt. Richardſon.
sp.p: All that ſhe ſays may be true by the Place. The Servants keep down a paire of Stayres in the Kitchin, and any one may come in or go out having ſo many Keys, and they not know it that are below.

sp.speaker: Lee.
sp.p: I went into the Chamber every morning as I went to Market.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Wild.
sp.p: Have a care what you ſay, and mind the Queſtion I ask you, Were you there on the Sunday in that Room where they ſay Sr. Edmondbury Godfrey's Body was laid?

sp.speaker: Lee.
sp.p: I cannot ſay that I was in that Room, but I called in at the Door every Day, and I was the laſt up every Night.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Wild.
sp.p: Ile ſay that for thee, thou haſt ſpoke with more care then any of them all.

div.stage: Then Daniel Gray was Examined

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt
sp.p: What can you ſay? What Queſtions do you ask him?

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: I deſire him to ſpeak what he can ſay, where I was thoſe 5 Days that Sr. Edmondbury Godfrey was miſſing.

sp.speaker: Gray.
sp.p: I kept my Brother Hill Company, from the 8th of October, till he took his Houſe, which was about the 22 or 23.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: What time did you uſe to go to Bed?

sp.speaker: Gray.
sp.p: About 9 or 10 a Clock at Night.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: What time did he go?

sp.speaker: Gray.
sp.p: When I did, but I did not ſee him go to Bed.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Where did you ly?

sp.speaker: Gray.
sp.p: At my owne Houſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſt.
sp.p: And you went home about 8 or 9 a Clock at Night to go to Bed?

sp.speaker: Gray.
sp.p: Yes I did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Jones.
sp.p: You ſay he took his Houſe the 8th of October, when did he go thither?

sp.speaker: Gray.
sp.p: Yes, he took his Houſe the 8th of October, but he did not go thither till the one or two and twentieth?

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolb.
sp.p: But you cannot tell what he did at night.

sp.speaker: Gray.
sp.p: No not I.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Dolbin.
sp.p: But you were in his Company till 8 or 9 a Clock at Night?

sp.speaker: Gray.
sp.p: Yes my Lord I was.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: How far did you live off of him?

sp.speaker: Gray.
sp.p: About a Bows ſhoot.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Look you Mr. Hill he does you no ſervice at all, for he ſayes he left you about 8 or 9 a Clock at Night, and he does not know what you did afterwards. Have you any more?

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Robert How.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Come what ſay you?

sp.speaker: How. My Lord,
sp.p:
I met with Mr. Hill the 5th of October, he asked me whither I was going, I told him home, I wiſh ſaid he you would go a little back with me, I am about taking of an Houſe, and I would have you view the Repairs, accordingly we did go, and treated in the Houſe
about an agreement, for ſaid he I will not agree with you, to the Landlord, till we know what muſt be repaired. On Tueſday morning we met again about 8 a Clock.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: What day of the Month was that?

How. the Eight. And a Wedneſday about Noon we began to work for him, to repaire his Houſe, and wee wrought that Week every Day, and for twelve Days and an half in all, and he was every Day with us looking after Coals or Beer or ſomething. on Saturday the 12th of October we Dined together, and parted with him about one or two a Clock, and about two a Clock I went back again to my Work, and he ſaid he was going towards Covent Garden in St. James, but he came back again, and I was gon firſt, I asked my Man whether he was gon or no, he ſaid, he was there, but did not ſtay.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: What time was that?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: A little before Night.

sp.speaker: L. C. Juſt.
sp.p: What Hour did your Man ſay that he was there?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: About an Hour before they left Work.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: What time was that?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: About four a Clock I think it was.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Can you ſay where he was that Night?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: No I cannot.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: What Religion are you of, are you not a Proteſtant?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord I think ſo.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: My Lord askes you, are you a Proteſtant.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: I was never bred up in the Proteſtant Religion.

sp.speaker: Mr. Prance.
sp.p: He is a Catholick my Lord, he was the Queens Carpenter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Dolben.
sp.p: Nay now you ſpoyl all, you muſt do Pennance for this, what deny your Church?

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: What time was it a Saturday Morning I was with you?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: About nine a Clock.

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: How long did he ſtay?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: From nine to two.

sp.speaker: L. C. J
sp.p: Are you ſure 'twas Nine?

sp.speaker: How
sp.p: No man can ſwear punctually to an hour.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What think you of Ten?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.p: It was thereabouts.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder.
sp.p: If I am rightly informed by the Clerks, he is Outlawed for Recuſancy.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Is he ſo? pray let us know that.

div.stage: Harcourt, one of the Clerks of the Crown Office.
div.p: My Lord, I have made out ſeveral Writs againſt him, for ſeveral years together, and could never get any of them Returned.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: He tells you that I was with him from Nine a clock on Saturday morning, till One.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Jones.
sp.p: But that is but as true as he is a Proteſtant, and how true that is, you know.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Here is another witneſs, Mr. Cutler.

sp.speaker: Tho. Cutler.
sp.p: Upon the Twelfth of October, Lawrence Hill did come into my houſe about four or five a clock in the evening, and he ſtaid there till between Seven or Eight, and then his wife came for him, and ſaid ſome Gentlewoman was ready for her Supper, and ſo he went home; and I ſaw him no more, till the day after he was taken.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Look you here, he ſpeaks only about Seven or Eight a clock. Well, have you any thing more to ſay?

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: There is one Richard Lazinby.

sp.speaker: Lazinby.
sp.p: My Lord, I was with him on Saturday the twelfth of October at the door, about twelve a clock.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And you dined with him and How.

sp.speaker: Lazinby.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But you did not ſee him afterwards?

sp.speaker: Lazinby.
sp.p: Yes, I did ſee him on Wedneſday night, from five to ſeven at night.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What time was he carried out of SomerſetHouſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: About eleven or twelve a clock at night.

sp.speaker: Lazinby.
sp.p: That is the laſt time I was with him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, have you any more?

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Here is one Mr. Archbold, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Archbold.
sp.p: My Lord, I had occaſion for a Taylor, and I came to this mans houſe, to ſeek for one Mr. Gray, that had formerly wrought for me.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When was that?

sp.speaker: Archbold.
sp.p: That was on Monday night. And he having formerly wrought for me, I found him at this mans houſe; ſo Mr. Gray asked me, What News? I told him, Very good News; For Praunce was taken for the Murder of Sir Edmundbury Godfrey. Sayes Hill, I am glad of that, I wiſh they were all taken. I came the next day after, and they told me he was taken out of his Bed, for the Marder of Sir Edmund bury Godfrey.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was it that very night that you came, that he was taken?

sp.speaker: Archbold.
sp.p: Yes, it was.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You ſaid he ſpoke of it before you at ſeven a clock, and you left him about nine, and he was taken that night, what then?

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: Why, then I had time enough to make my Eſcape, if I had thought my ſelf Guilty.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: As no doubt you would, if you had thought they would have been ſo nimble with you.

sp.speaker: Archbold.
sp.p: He knew it the day before.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, have you any more to ſay?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hill.
sp.p: There is Mr. Ravenſcroft, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What, that Ravenſcroft that is ſent away?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hill.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Then the Marſhal muſt ſend for him, if he be a witneſs for the Priſoner. In the mean time, What can you ſay for your ſelf, Mr. Green?

sp.speaker: Greene.
sp.p: My Lord, I would call my Landlord and his wife.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What are their Names?

sp.speaker: Greene.
sp.p: James Warrier, and his wife.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Call in Greene's wife, and all her Witneſſes.

div.stage: Then Mrs. Hill, the Priſoners wife, offered a Paper to the Court, containing Obſervations upon the Indictment, which ſhe deſired them to read; but it was refuſed, and ſhe bid to give it her Husband. Then James Warrier was examined.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What ſay you to your Landlord?

sp.speaker: Greene.
sp.p: I ask him no Queſtions at all, but deſire him to tell what he knows.

sp.speaker: Warrier.
sp.p: I will ſay, that the twelfth of October, he was at my houſe half an hour after ſeven, and he was not out of my houſe till after ten.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How can you remember that day? What day of the week was it?

sp.speaker: Warrier.
sp.p: It was a Saturday.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How do you remember it was ſo?

sp.speaker: Warrier.
sp.p: I have recollected my memory.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: By what?

sp.speaker: Warrier.
sp.p: By my work, and every thing exactly.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When did you begin to recollect your ſelf?

sp.speaker: Warrier.
sp.p: A pretty while ago.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How long after Sir Edmund bury Godfrey was murdered?

sp.speaker: Warrier.
sp.p: A month after.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What made you to recollect your ſelf a month after?

sp.speaker: Warrier.
sp.p: Becauſe he was in Priſon in the Gatehouſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When was he taken up?

sp.speaker: Warrier.
sp.p: He was taken up in Somerſet-houſe, and not in my houſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But when did you recollect your ſelf?

sp.speaker: Warrier.
sp.p: When he was in Priſon.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But I pray remember the time when you did recollect your ſelf, and the occaſion that made you recollect your ſelf when he was taken up.

sp.speaker: Warrier.
sp.p: I remember it very well, for he had been in my houſe but 14 dayes before he was taken up.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Stringer.
sp.p: He was not taken up for the Mudrer of Sir Edmund bury Godfrey, till the 24 of December.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Wyld.
sp.p: Pray did you never think of this till he was in Priſon?

sp.speaker: Warrier.
sp.p: It was when he was taken up.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But pray when you came to recollect your ſelf, how did you come to do it?

sp.speaker: Warrier.
sp.p: I recollected it by my work.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But what gave you occaſion to recollect your ſelf ſince he was in Gaol?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Stringer.
sp.p: My Lord, he was put into Gaol, for refuſing to take the Oaths; but he was not at all charged with the Death of Sir Edmund-bury Godfrey at that time.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When was he put in for the Death of Sir Edmundbury?

sp.speaker: Sir The. Stringer.
sp.p: The 24th of December.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Then there is all the remaining part of October, all November, and the former part of December was paſt, how could you recollect your ſelf of the particular day?

sp.speaker: Warrier.
sp.p: I call'd it to mind by my work.

sp.speaker: Capt. Richardſon.
sp.p: My Lord, I will rectifie this miſtake: ſince their Arraignment, I went to them, to know what Witneſſes they had, and Greene told me of his Landlord and Landlady; I then asked them, If they could ſay any thing as to this particular day? And they ſaid they could not do him any good at all.

sp.speaker: Warrier.
sp.p: I did not then call it to memory.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When did you call it to memory?

sp.speaker: Warrier.
sp.p: I did ſay I could not do it then preſently, as I have done ſince in five or ſix dayes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How could you recollect it then?

sp.speaker: Warrier.
sp.p: By the time he came into my houſe, which was a week before, and by the work that was done.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What could the work do as to this? Can you tell by that, any thing that is done at any time? Where were you the ninth of November laſt?

sp.speaker: Warrier.
sp.p: Truly I can't tell.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why how came you then to recollect what you did the twelfth of October, when you did not know where you were the ninth of November?

sp.speaker: Warrier.
sp.p: I can tell a great many tokens, he was but 14 or 15 dayes in our houſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What did he do the twelfth of October, that you remember ſo particularly that day?

sp.speaker: Warrier.
sp.p: Sir, I remember other dayes beſides that; but I ſay I never knew the man out after nine a clock, in my life.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Have you any body elſe, for this man I can't tell what to make on't?

sp.speaker: Greene.
sp.p: Here is the man's wife to give Evidence.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Firſt conſider what you ſay.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Warrier.
sp.p:
To tell you the truth, I thought the man ſo clear of this Fact, that I never trouble my head with it; but when Captain Richardſon came to my houſe, I told him that he was never in our houſe by day-time, except being Cuſ •
ion-layer in the Chappel, he uſed to come at half an hour after eleven, and many times he did deſire me, becauſe we were
Proteſtants, to put in a little fleſh meat with ours; ſometimes he would ſit down and eat his meat in the Kitchin, and his Wife with him; and his Wife would ſay to him, 'tis a troubleſom time, pray ſee that you come home betimes. I did not at all remember the day of the month at the firſt, nor the Action; but my Husband and I have ſince remembred. We were deſired by them once to eat a Fowl with them, and my Husband did command me the Sunday after to invite them to dinner with us, and I went in the morning very early, I think, and bought a dozen of Pidgeons, and put them in a Pye, and we had a Loine of Pork roaſted; and when he was gone to the Chappel on Saturday in the afternoon, his Wife came to me and ſaid, my Husband is not well, and when he comes home will ask for ſomething of Broth; and away ſhe went to Market to buy ſomething to make Broth of. While ſhe was at Market, her Husband came home, and asked where his Wife was? why, Mr. Greene, ſaid I, ſhe is gone to Market: what an old Fool, ſaid he, is this, to go out ſo late, ſuch a night as this is? but ſaid he again, I will go to the Coffee-houſe, and drink a Diſh of Coffee, and pray tell my wife ſo. In the mean time ſhe returned, and by that time ſhe had been above a little while, he came in again. And Mr. Greene being there, my Husband came in, and called to me, prithee, ſweetheart, what haſt thou got for my Supper? prithee, ſaid I, ſweetheart thou art always calling for thy Victuals when thou comeſt in. Then Mr. Greene goes to the ſtairs, and calls to his Wife, and bids her bring him down ſome victuals, and ſhe brings down the Bread and Cheeſe, and he ſtayed there till it was nine a Clock; and then ſaith Mr. Greene to his Wife, let us go up, for there is a Fire.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What day was this all this while?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Warrier.
sp.p: Why, it was the Saturday fortnight after Michaelmas day.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why might it not be that day three weeks?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Warrier.
sp.p: It was that day he was miſſing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. G.
sp.p: Why there was no Alarum taken of it a Sunday.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When did you begin to recollect what day it was, that they ſaid he was miſſing?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Warrier.
sp.p: On Friday morning our Milkman came and told us, that one Mr. Godfrey was found murdered; now I knew one of the Exchange of that name, and thought it might be he. And when we went up with him to his Chamber, we ſate there till the Tattooe beat.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: All the thing is, how do you know it was this Saturday?

sp.speaker: Mrs. War.
sp.p: It was the Saturday fortnight after Michaelmas day.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. Dolben.
sp.p: Are you ſure it was the Saturday fortnight after Michaelmas day?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Warier.
sp.p: Yes, we did look upon the Almanack, and reckon it ſo.

sp.speaker: M. J. Dolben.
sp.p: Then that was the 10th of October.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Why you told him you could do him no good, and indeed you do not.

sp.speaker: M. J. Jones.
sp.p: You and your wife ſpeak of the ſame time, don't you?

sp.speaker: Warrier.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L C. J.
sp.p: Have you any more Greene?

sp.speaker: Capt. Richardſon.
sp.p: There is the Maid, let her come in.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: VVhat ſay you Maid?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: I can ſay that he came in the Saturday fortnight after Quarter-day, pretty betimes.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Can you ſpeak of any other time beſides that Saturday fortnight?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: I can tell he came in every night before 9 a clock.

sp.speaker: Greene.
sp.p: I can take my Oath I was never out of my Lodging after 9 a clock.

sp.speaker: Hill.
sp.p: My Lord, here is Mr. Ravenſcroft now.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Mr. Ravenſcroft, what can you ſay?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ravenſcroft.
sp.p: VVhat I can ſay, my Lord, is this; This Lawrence Hill, I have known him 13 or 14 Years, and he ſerved my elder Brother ſo long very faithfully. Afterwards he lived with Dr. Godwin towards the latter end of the two laſt Years, and he married my Mothers Maid.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: VVhat Religion are you of?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ravenſcroft.
sp.p: My Father and Mother were Proteſtants.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But you are a Papiſt, are you not?

sp.speaker: Mr. Ravenſcroft.
sp.p: I have not ſaid I am a Papiſt yet.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Dolben.
sp.p: In the mean time I ſay you are one.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ravenſe.
sp.p: Do you ſo, then pray go to Southwark and ſee.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. G.
sp.p: My Lord, I think, he hath taken the Oaths of Allegiance and Supremacy.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, pray Sir go on with your Story.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ravenſcroft.
sp.p:
If it pleaſe you, upon a Saturday, a little before Chriſtmaſs, there was ſomebody taken, I think it was one M. Praunce, for I never ſaw the man, neither do I know him
at all: and it was reported that he was taken upon the Death of Sir Edmund-Bury Godfrey, and I was glad to hear it. My houſe was in the Savoy. and my Fathers houſe is in Holborn; and I uſed often to go and ſee my father, and coming home again, I went to ſee the Maid at her new Houſe, ſhe had not been long there, and ſhe was ſtanding at the Dore of the Houſe. I asked her what News? ſays ſhe, here hath been a man here that tells us that Praunce hath diſcover'd ſeveral of the Murderers of Sir Edmund-Bury Godfrey, and they talk up and down ſtrangely of it, and ask me whether my Husband be acquainted with him? then ſaid I to her, is he? ſhe anſwered me very well, they have been often together, and ſo ſhe told me the people did mutter and talk of her Husband; but ſaid I, what ſays your Husband to it? ſays ſhe, he deſies Praunce and all his works. Said I, where is your Husband? ſaid ſhe, he is within; I was very glad to hear it, for, ſaid I, he living in Somerſet Houſe, and being acquainted with Praunce, I am glad to hear that your Husband can be ſo Couragious; ſo I went away and came again thither the next morning, and found he was taken the night before. All that I ſay then, is that it, was a good Evidence of his innocency, that when he had notice of it he did not Fly.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: So then your diſcourſe was after Archbold had been there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ravenſcroft.
sp.p: Archbold was there before me, and had ſpoken this in their Company. I ſpake with her that night, and the next morning too; and all that I ſay is, it Fight be a ſign of Guilt, as no doubt it is, Adam ubi es? and Couragiouſneſs is a ſign of innocency, then this man is innocent.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But you ſay ſhe told you they were acquainted.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ravenſcroft.
sp.p: My Lord, I have one thing more to ſay. Upon the occaſion of theſe things, this Woman hath been often with me, and hath deſired to know of me what Defence ſhe ſhould make, for I ſaw Hill's Wife and Berry's Wife were all ſimple people without Defence for themſelves, and they did deſire that I would Examin and ſee ſome of the Witneſſes and ſee how it was, and ſhe had gotten me ſome papers, and I Conferred them together, there are witneſſes that will atteſt the Copy.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. G.
sp.p: What is all this to the purpoſe? only this Gentleman hath a mind to ſhew that he can ſpeak Latin.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ravenſcroft.
sp.p: I thank God I can ſpeak Latin as well as any man in the Court.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: VVell, all this is nothing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ravenſcroft.
sp.p: I declare it my ſelf, if this man were Guilty, rather than I would ſpeak for him, if there wanted a Hangman, I would do it my ſelf.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well Berry, what have you to ſay?

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: I deſire Nicholas Trollop, and Nicholas Wright, and Gabriel Hasket, and Elizabeth Wilkes, and Corporal Collet may be called.

div.stage: Corporal William Collet firſt Examined.

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: Did not you place a Sentinel on wedneſday night?

sp.speaker: Collet.
sp.p: What wedneſday do you ſpeak of Sir?

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: That night the Queen went from Somerſet Houſe to Whitehall.

sp.speaker: Collet.
sp.p: Yes. This Nicholas Trollop I placed there firſt, the 16. of October.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How do you remember that?

sp.speaker: Collet.
sp.p: Becauſe I have been called to an account before, and have given good Reaſons for it. Our Company was at Somerſet Houſe when the King came from New-market, and the Queen went to Whitehall. Afterwards we were bid to fetch our Sentinels off about 3 or 4 of the Clock in the afternoon.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you leave any Souldiers there?

sp.speaker: Collet.
sp.p: No, we did not, all our Company went to Whitehall.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Dolben.
sp.p: Are you ſure there were no Souldiers that night there?

sp.speaker: Collet.
sp.p: Yes, we were commanded with a party to go thither again that night.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What did you do then?

sp.speaker: Collet.
sp.p: I placed the Sentinels by the Porters order.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who was that, Berry?

sp.speaker: Collet.
sp.p: No, it was one that uſed to go about, and give Orders where we ſhould ſet them.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How did you place them?

sp.speaker: Collet.
sp.p: This man I placed from 7 to 10, then Nicolas Wright releived him at 10, and ſtayed till one.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: At what place?

sp.speaker: Collet
sp.p: To the Strand-ward.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſtice Wild.
sp.p: That was the Gate they carried him out at.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you hear, whereabouts did you ſet the Sentinels? within the gate?

sp.speaker: Collet.
sp.p: Yes, within the wicket.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: That way he was carried out.

sp.speaker: Nicholas Wright.
sp.p: There was no Sedan came out in my time.

sp.speaker: Trollop.
sp.p: There was one came in in my time while I ſtood there.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Was it an empty Sedan?

sp.speaker: Trollop.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe it was, but we had no Order to keep any out.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Wild.
sp.p: But you might know whether it was an empty Sedan or no, by the going of it through the Wicket.

sp.speaker: Collet.
sp.p: There is an empty Sedan that ſtands there every Night.

sp.speaker: Trollop.
sp.p: It was ſet down within the Gate.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt Jones.
sp.p: If any Sedan had gone out, you would not have ſtaid them, would you?

sp.speaker: Collet.
sp.p: No, my Lord, we had no Order to ſtop any.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Dolben.
sp.p: How can you then be poſitive, that no one did go out?

sp.speaker: Trollop.
sp.p: None did go out again in my time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt Dolben.
sp.p: Could not the Porter open the Gate, as well as you?

sp.speaker: Collet.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, he could, but I ſhould have ſeen him then: he did not open it in my time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Wild.
sp.p: Let me ask you but one Queſtion; Did not you go to drink, nor tipple all that time?

sp.speaker: Trollop.
sp.p: No, nor walk a Pikes length off the Place of Centry.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Wild.
sp.p: Has not Berry an Houſe there, hard by?

sp.speaker: Trollop.
sp.p: Yes, but I did not drink one drop.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Dolben.
sp.p: How can you remember ſo particularly, ſo long ago?

sp.speaker: Trollop.
sp.p: Why, I was twice before the Committee.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Dolben.
sp.p: But how long agoe was it, that you were queſtioned about this thing, after this Night?

sp.speaker: Trollop.
sp.p: A matter of a Month, or Six Weeks.

sp.speaker: Collet.
sp.p: For we were examined before Praunce was taken up.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: You Trollop, Can you ſay whether it was the Sedan that uſed to be within?

sp.speaker: Trollop.
sp.p: No, I cannot, but it was brought in in my time, and did not go out again.

div.stage: [Then Gabriell Hasket was examined.]

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: You Stood there, Sir, from One to Four.

sp.speaker: Hasket.
sp.p: Yes, after the Clock ſtruck One, I was put Sentinell, and ſtood till Four.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: What Night?

sp.speaker: Hasket.
sp.p: That Night the King came from New-market, and the Queen went from Somerſet-houſe.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: What day of the Month was that?

sp.speaker: Hasket.
sp.p: The Sixteenth.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: What day of the Week?

sp.speaker: Hasket.
sp.p: Wedneſday.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Did not you drink at Berry's then?

sp.speaker: Hasket.
sp.p: No, I did not.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Did you ſee Berry then?

sp.speaker: Hasket.
sp.p: No I did not.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: He was gone before you came.

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: I was faſt enough a Bed at that time.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Well, what ſay you more?

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: Here is my Maid, Elizabeth Minſhaw, to give her Evidence, where I was that Night the Queen went from Somerſet-houſe.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Jones.
sp.p: What can you ſay?

sp.speaker: Minſhaw.
sp.p: May it pleaſe you, my Lord, my Maſter was within Doors, and about the Gate, when the Queen went away.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Who is your Maſter?

sp.speaker: Minſhaw.
sp.p: Mr. Berry. He was about the Gates all the Forenoon.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: When was that?

sp.speaker: Minſhaw.
sp.p: The 16th. Octob. Wedneſday. And aſſoon as the Queen was gone, my Maſter went out to Bowls; and when he came home again, he ſaid he had been at Bowls.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: What time did he come home?

sp.speaker: Minſhaw.
sp.p: It was Dusky, and he was not abſent all Night an hour, till he went to Bed.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Wild.
sp.p: When did he go to Bed?

sp.speaker: Minſhaw.
sp.p: My Lord, I ſuppoſe he went to Bed about Twelve a Clock.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Wild.
sp.p: They do not charge him with any thing but what was done about the Gate.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Dolben.
sp.p: What time did you go to bed that Night?

sp.speaker: Minſhaw.
sp.p: Why I went to Bed about Twelve a Clock.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Dolben.
sp.p: And you ſaw him no more that Night?

sp.speaker: Minſhaw.
sp.p: No, my Lord, but he muſt go through my Room to go to Bed at Night, and therefore I ſuppoſe he was a Bed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hill.
sp.p: I deſire Mr. Praunce may Swear why he did deny all this?

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Stand up, Mr. Praunce, that Gentlewoman does deſire to know, what induced you to deny what you had ſaid?

sp.speaker: Mr. Praunce.
sp.p: It was becauſe of my Trade, my Lord; and for fear of loſing my Employment from the Queen, and the Catholicks, which was the moſt of my buſineſs, and becauſe I had not my Pardon.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hill.
sp.p: I deſire he may Swear whether he were not tortured?

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Dolben.
sp.p: Anſwer her, were you tortured to make this Confeſſion?

sp.speaker: Mr. Praunce.
sp.p: No, my Lord, Captain Richardſon hath uſed me as civilly as any man in England; all that time that I have been there, I have wanted for nothing.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: See what he ſays; That he did not make this Confeſſion by any Torture, but he made his Recantation through fear, and the thoughts of death, becauſe he had no Pardon; and fear that he might live in want, by the loſs of the Trade, prevailed with him to deny what he had confeſſed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hill.
sp.p: It was reported about Town, that he was tortured.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Jones.
sp.p: No, it was no ſuch thing; it was only the tortures of his Conſcience, for being an Actor in ſo great a Sin.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hill.
sp.p: There are ſeveral about the Court, that heard him cry out: And he knows all theſe things to be as falſe, as God is true; and you will ſee it declared hereafter, when 'tis too late.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Do you think he would Swear Three men out of their Lives for nothing?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hill.
sp.p: I deſire he may be Sworn to that particular thing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ju. Jon.
sp.p: He is upon his Oath already, and Swears all this upon his Oath.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hill.
sp.p: Well, I am disſatisfied; my Witneſſes were not rightly examined, they were modeſt, and the Court laught at them.

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: The Sentinels that were at the Gate all Night, let nothing out.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Why you could open the Gate your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Berry.
sp.p: He ſays, he could have ſeen if the Gate had been open; and that as he ſaw, the Gates were never open'd.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Dolben.
sp.p: Well, the Jury have heard all, and will conſider of it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Hill.
sp.p: Here is another Witneſs, my Lord; Mr. Chevins.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Well Sir, what ſay you?

sp.speaker: Chevins.
sp.p: I have nothing to ſay, but that I heard Mr. Praunce deny all.

sp.speaker: Lord C. J.
sp.p: Why he does not deny that now. Well, have you any more?

sp.speaker: Chevins.
sp.p: We have no more.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attor. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, I muſt crave leave to ſpeak a word, or two; and the Evidence having been ſo very long, I ſhall be exceeding ſhort. I intended (when I began to open the Evidence) to have made ſome Obſervations after the Evidence ended; to ſhew how each part of it did agree, and how the Main was ſtrengthned by concurrent Circumſtances. But in truth, the King's Evidence did fall out much better than I could expect, and the defence of the Priſoners much weaker than I could foreſee. So that, I think, the proof againſt the Priſoners is ſo ſtrong; and ſo little hath been alleadged by them in their Defence, that it would be but loſs of time to do, what I at firſt intended. Only I will obſerve, that Mr. Bedlow doth agree with Mr. Praunce, as far forth as is poſſible; that is, in thoſe parts of the Fact of which he pretends to have any knowledge. Yet had they never any communication one with another, as both have Sworn. And your Lordſhip will obſerve in how many particulars they do agree; namely, as to the Dark Lanthorn, as to the Covering of the Body in the Room; how they intended to carry the Body out in a Sedan, and the reſt. So that if they had laid their heads together to contrive a Story, they could hardly have agreed in ſo many circumſtances; and yet this they do without diſcourſing with each other beforehand.

My Lord, I muſt likewiſe obſerve to you, that the Servants of the Plow Ale-houſe concur as to the Meetings there: The Maid agrees as to the Priſoners coming to Sir Edmondbury Godfrey's Houſe, and to the time, viz. that Saturday Morning; nay, to the very Hours of Nine, or Ten a Clock;
That the Conſtables Relation of the poſture in which the Body was found in the Field, doth perfectly agree with the Account that the Murtherers gave thereof to Mr. Praunce the next Morning. The Chirurgions do agree with Mr. Praunce, as to the manner of Sir Edmonbury Godfrey's being killed, the ſtrangling, the bruiſing of his Stomach, the twiſting of his Neck. And the Witneſſes from Bow make it out, that Dethick was ſent for; that they had a Dinner there. The Boy proves that he over-heard them reading ſomething about Sir Edmondbury Godfrey, and that they were very Merry; and that for his liſtning, he was threatned to be kickt down ſtairs.

So that, I think, there never was an Evidence that was better fortified with circumſtances than this: My Lord, I ſhall be bold to ſay, here is certainly as much Evidence, as the matter is capable of.
